characters: GET OUT OF HERE, YOU LITTLE THIEF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From far above it looks like a great clockwork. We are looking down on the Grand Hall of the Paris Train Station. It is crowded. People bustle back and forth. Like the gears and wheels of a clock. A precise, beautiful machine. We float down... Under the great iron girders... Moving through the station... Past kiosks and shops... Weaving among commuters... We stop at a clock set into the station wall. Behind the ironwork dial we see a face peering out. HUGO CABRET looks at us. He is a serious-looking boy of around 12. Long hair. It is 1931.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo turns away from the dial and moves through the tunne behind the clock. A serpentine maze of passageways. Behind the walls. Hugo’s secret world. He moves quickly up and down spiral staircases ... duckin through tiny openings ... swerving in and out of dark passages ... up and down, back and forth... Like an elaborate game of Chutes and Ladders. He finally stops. Peers through another clock dial into a different part of the station.  He sees... A TOY BOOTH. Bedraggled and struggling. A counter filled with windup t dolls and little games. GEORGES, a grim old man with a white goatee, sits at the counter of the booth. Hugo watches. ISABELLE appears from inside the booth and talks to the o man. She has a book under her arm. She is a lively, imaginative girl about Hugo’s age. She h a charming Louise Brooks haircut. Isabelle argues a bit with Georges. He snaps at her. Upse she hurries off. Hugo watches her go. Then he turns his gaze to the toys on the counter. He sees the old man aimlessly wind a TOY MOUSE. It skitte across the counter. The old man crosses his arms. Falls asleep. Hugo stares at the toy mouse. Then he moves. He skitters through a series of passages and opens an air vent. He carefully climbs out, into the station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo creeps to the Toy Booth. The toy mouse is there on the counter. Georges still appears to be asleep. Hugo stops. Waits. Looks around. Carefully reaches for the toy mouse-- But--  Georges’ eyes snap open--! He grabs Hugo--! Hugo drops the toy mouse-- It falls and breaks-- Hugo struggles. Georges holds him firm.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Got you at last, my little thief. Quick, empty your pockets!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You’re hurting me!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Empty your pockets or I’1ll call the Station Inspector! Do as I say! The threat of the Station Inspector terrifies Hugo. He quickly empties his pockets. Dozens of objects. Screws Nails. Bits of metal and glass. Tiny pieces of clockworks Cogs and wheels.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: And the other one.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: There’s nothing in it!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: (Starts to call) Where’s the Station Inspector...?! Hugo empties his last pocket. Reluctantly giving up a precious object: An old cardboard NOTEBOOK. Georges flips through it-- He sees words, pictures, engineering diagrams, schematics clockwork drawings-- Then he suddenly stops flipping-- Shocked-- It is like he has seen a ghost-- He stares at a page of the notebook--  4. A drawing of a MECHANICAL MAN man with clockwork innards. elegant and complex mechanism. But it is the face of the mechanical man that transfixes. Strangely passive and yet expressing a sort of sadness. O wisdom. It is a haunting face. Georges thumbs through a few pages of the notebook. It is like an old FLIPBOOK. The mechanical man’s face changes perspective as the page flip past. Like primitive animation. Georges stops. Slowly closes the notebook.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: (whispers) Ghosts... He turns to Hugo. Sadness turning to rage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Did you draw these pictures?! (no response) Did you draw these pictures?! Hugo tries to pull away. Georges’ grip is iron.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Where did you steal this?!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I didn’t steal it!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: A thief and a liar. Georges releases Hugo.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Get out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Give me my notebook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is no longer your notebook, it is my notebook and I'll do with it what I want. Maybe I’1l just burn it.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Then tell me who did the drawings. Hugo glares at him. Says nothing. Georges suddenly SLAMS his fist down on the counter. All toys jump.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT OF HERE, YOU LITTLE THIEF
dialogues.text: His shout echoes around the station... Reverberating from walls ... ceiling ... girders ... wind +.. all around the cavernous station... To the ears of... MAXIMILIAN -- an enormous Doberman Pinscher. His ears perk up. His head tilts dangerously. He glares. Listening. Alert. THE STATION INSPECTOR, his master, glances down at him. The Station Inspector is a tall man in a bottle-green coa flamboyantly frightening ... Made even more menacing by a squeaking metal brace that bolts around one leg. He’s lik partly mechanical man. He and Maximilian are twin figures of implacable severity

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Maximilian? ... What do you hear? -.-.- Do you hear ... malfeasance?! The dog growls dangerously. Strains at his leash. The Station Inspector smiles.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Go!  He releases the terrible hound-- Maximilian bolts-- The Station Inspector follows -- he is remarkably agile w his iron-shrouded leg, moving like an elegant spider-- Maximilian tears through the station-- People leap aside in shock and terror as the ferocious do sweeps past-- The Station Inspector spiders after him, his boots poundi over the polished floors, his leg brace squeaking wildly- Maximilian’s nails slips as he rounds a corner, he almost spins out, but doesn’t-- For ahead he sees-- Hugo. At the toy booth. Hugo sees the dog and sprints-- Running away in desperation-- Maximilian pursues-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chase is on! Huge weaves through pedestrians -- whips around corners - races down and up stairs -- leaping over luggage-- Maximilian on his heels-- The Station Inspector follows relentlessly-- Insane whirlwind momentum as the station zips past-- Hugo pants for air, glancing back in panic-- Maximilian is closer and closer-- The Station Inspector spiders after them -- his leg brace screeching -- his green coat flaring out behind him like bat’s wings-- Hugo speeds through a CAFE, agilely weaving between the little tables and the sniffy French waiters--  7. Maximilian follows, not quite so agilely, upsetting table and waiters-- Chaos--! MADAME EMILIE, the shy older woman who runs the cafe, scr and clutches her beloved little DACHSHUND to her chest-- The dachshund barks furiously at Maximilian-- Hugo loops around a table-- Where a man who looks suspiciously like James Joyce is ha a demitasse with a man who looks suspiciously like Salvad Dali-- They are agog as Hugo races around them ... followed by Maximilian ... followed by the Station Inspector-- Hugo finally sprints away from the cafe. Tearing through the crowded terminal again. The Station Inspector calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: STOP THAT CHILD
dialogues.text: MONSIEUR FRICK, the shy older gentleman who runs a NEWSPA KIOSK across from the cafe, makes a half-hearted grab for Hugo-— But Hugo suddenly-- Dives-- Sliding on the polished floor between Monsieur Frick’s le Then he’s up and gone-- Monsieur Frick looks up, alarmed, leaps to the side as-- Maximilian thunders past-- The Station Inspector follows -- by now Hugo has disappea around a corner-- The Station Inspector and Maximilian rip around the corne top speed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hugo is gone--!  8. And ahead -- a MATRONLY WOMAN and her two UNIFORMED VALET carrying towers of boxes from the most exclusive stores i Paris-- The Station Inspector and Maximilian try to stop -- but c -- momentum too great -- collision inevitable--

dialogues.speaker: BAM
dialogues.text: Boxes flying everywhere -- Valets knocked aside -- Matron Woman bellowing like Margaret Dumont -- the Station Inspe and Maximilian tangled! We move away from the chaos... Toward a wall... To find Hugo ... Safe behind an air vent ... Watching. He sees the Station Inspector pull himself up. Squeak his brace once in anger. Thwarted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo weaves through the tunnels. Comes to an iron door and enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is like stepping into the heart of a mechanical toy. Wheels and gears hang everywhere. There are rows of jars filled with cogs, screws and bits of toys. Tools. Scaveng furniture. Hugo’s home and makeshift workshop. He sits on a battered old trunk for a moment. Disheartene He pulls out a large POCKET WATCH. Looks at it. Takes a deep breath. Time to go to work. He picks up a bucket of heavy tools and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge moves through the tunnels.  9. Stops behind a large clock. He can see the station throug the clock face. He checks the time on his pocket watch. Then he uses tools from the bucket to wind the clock’s mechanism. Then he continues on. Opens a hatch and climbs down a rickety ladder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He climbs down into a large clock that is suspended from ceiling of the Grand Hall. Clock dials and intricate work surround him on all four sides. While he winds all four clockworks, he looks out into the station below... He sees Madame Emilie, the shy older woman who runs the c cooing to her little dachshund. He sees Monsieur Frick, the shy older gentleman who runs newspaper kiosk, watching her. Monsieur Frick summons up his nerve. Timidly approaches h Bows rather formally. She is delighted. He tries to pet t dachshund. The dog snaps at him. Madame Emilie is mortifi Monsieur Frick retreats. Hugo climbs up, out of the clock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo continues on. Climbs a ladder to a narrow passage that overlooks a platform...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo moves along a narrow passage above a station platfor He must kneel to wind this clock, which is at his foot le Through the clock he sees... MONSIEUR ROULEAU is a flamboyant young artist. He is pain at an easel. He is a Surrealist. His painting is wildly abstract.  10. Some SUBURBAN COMMUTERS stop to look. They ridicule the painting. Monsieur Rouleau tries to ignore them. Hugo feels bad for him. Hugo completes winding the clock and goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo climbs and climbs and climbs. His bucket of tools is heavy. An endless staircase inside a high tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo emerges at the very top of the station. An enormous clock. The motors and gears of the mechanism huge, bigger than he is. Hugo puts a crank into the works uses all his strength to turn it. It is like something out of METROPOLIS. And beyond the clock... Paris. A panoramic view. Somewhat unreal. Like an exquisite toy model. Exhausted, Hugo finally completes winding the clock. He takes a moment to look over the majestic city. And we fade to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grand Hall is almost empty. Georges, in his hat and coat, is closing up the shop. Pul down a heavy grate. Hugo stands silently behind him.  11.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: (not turning) I know you’re there ... What’s your name, boy?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Hugo ... Hugo Cabret.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Stay away from me, Hugo Cabret, or I’‘1l drag you to the Station Inspector's office and he’1ll lock you up in his little cell and you'll never get out and you’1ll never go to school and you'll never get married and have children of your own to take things that don’t belong to them. Georges completes locking the gate and goes. Hugo follows. They walk through the echoing station.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Give me back my notebook.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I am going home to burn your notebook. Georges sweeps through the doors, leaving the station. Hugo stops at the doors, hesitates for a moment. He is extremely uncomfortable at the idea of leaving the station. It has become his whole world. Everything beyond threatening. But his need now is great. He steels himself, takes a bre and pushes through the doors, following Georges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges walks through the dark streets of Paris. Hugo follows. It is the spirit of the great city we see, not the real thing. Shapes and silhouettes of buildings. Architectural details. Sounds. Illusion.  12. Like a lovingly crafted 1930's movie set.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You can’t burn my notebook.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: And who’s to stop me? Hugo wasn’t prepared for leaving the station. It’s cold. has no winter coat. He pulls his clothes tightly around h Later... Georges walks on. Hugo follows. A little closer. Later... Georges walks under a street lamp. Hugo follows. A little closer still. Later... Georges walks over a bridge. Hugo follows. A little closer still. Later... Georges moves through a sinister alley. Hugo, scared, is walking right next to him now. Georges ignores him. Snow begins to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges and Hugo walk through a graveyard. Twisted trees. The shape of tombstones. Like Lean’s GREAT EXPECTATIONS. Snow continues to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges walks to a decrepit apartment building. Right acr from the graveyard. Shabby part of town.  13. The old man stops and unlocks the chipped front door with large key. Hugo waits. Georges enters the building and, without a glance, slams door shut behind him. Hugo stands there. Snow falls. Hugo steps back, studies the building. He sees Georges enter an upper floor apartment. Sees a handsome older woman -- his wife -- greet him. They disap from view. Huge scans the other windows. He sees Isabelle, the girl the Toy Booth, in another room of the apartment. She is reading by the window. Hugo watches her. Snow collects on his head. He finally tosses a pebble up at the window. Isabelle loo down. Sees him. She stares at him quizzically. He motions for her to come down. She is intrigued but unsure. He motions. Begs. Please. Isabelle smiles. She loves nothing more than an adventure. She disappears from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo stands shivering. Isabelle runs to him.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Who are you?  14.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Your grandfather stole my notebook. I need to get it back before he burns it.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Papa Georges isn’t my grandfather and he isn’t a thief! He told me all about you, young gentleman. You’re nothing but a... a reprobate! She is delighted with the word. He doesn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Can you help me get inside?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: No. You have to go.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Not without my notebook--

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Why do you need it so badly?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I... I can’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Is it a secret?!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Good! I love secrets! Tell me this instant!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: If you won’t tell me you have to go.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Not without--

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I’‘1l get in trouble. Just go home! He won’t budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! I'11 make sure he doesn’t burn your notebook. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Trust me. He looks at her. He nods. He runs off. She watches him go. What a strange boy. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo enters. Still cold. He strikes a match. Lights a few candles. A golden glow fills the strange chamber. 15. Hugo takes out his pocket watch and hangs it on a special hook by the bed. Then he moves to a corner... There is something covered in an old sheet... He pulls off the sheet to reveal... The AUTOMATON. An amazing mechanical man. A couple feet tall. Exposed ge and levers. Clockworks and springs. In a state of disrepa We recognize the strange, haunting face from the drawings Hugo’s notebook. The Automaton sits at a little desk. Pen poised to write something. Hugo stares at the passive face of the Automaton. And remembers.  16.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is it...?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s called an Automaton. The color fades as we go six months back in time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The memory has the quality of a SILENT FILM. Black-and-wh Simple images. The flickering, glowing luminescence of ea movies. Hugo and his FATHER live in a poor, cramped garret. Big skylight. Paris beyond. An enormous full moon beyond that The Automaton -- now in much worse condition, battered an rusty, missing parts -- sits before Hugo and his Father.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: An Automaton...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER
dialogues.text: I found him abandoned in the attic of the museum.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What does he do?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER
dialogues.text: (tinkering with it) He’s a windup figure, like a music box ... This is the most complicated one I’ve ever seen by far. You see? This one can write.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (transfixed) Who built him?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER
dialogues.text: I would think a magician.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: A magician!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER
dialogues.text: That’s right. Magicians used machines like this when I was a boy. No one could figure out how they danced or walked or sang. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But the secret was always in the clockwork.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Can we fix it?!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know, Hugo, it’s awfully rusted and finding the parts would be... He sees Hugo’s disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO'S FATHER
dialogues.text: Of course we can fix it! We’re clock makers, aren’t we! ... But only when I’ve gotten through all my work at the shop and at the museum, you understand? Hugo hugs him. His father smiles. The Automaton seems to watch them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music. Hugo sweeps up as his father works fixing clocks. The tiny, cramped shop is a jumble of clocks, watches, ge movements, springs, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music. Hugo’s father winds and oils clocks in an old museum fill with Victorian curiosities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music. Hugo and his father work on the Automaton together. They huddle at the workbench. Hugo’s father patiently teaches him. Hugo learns eagerly. Hugo’s father stops to make a note.  18. We realize he is writing in the NOTEBOOK, the one Georges took.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music. Hugo’s father is working on a stubborn clock at the museu Then... The music stops... Hugo’s father slowly turns... Curious... He moves to a stairway... Looks down... He sees... A PILLAR OF FLAME. Raging right up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is very late. Hugo is working on the Automaton. The door opens. He turns eagerly:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I fixed the gears in the-- But it is not his father. It is his UNCLE CLAUDE. Unshaven. Greasy. Crude. Huge.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Uncle Claude...?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CLAUDE
dialogues.text: There was a fire. Your father’s dead. Pack your things quickly. You’re coming with me.  19. Hugo stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo lugs the heavy Automaton, covered in a sheet, as he follows Uncle Claude through the empty streets. Hugo struggles to keep up with Uncle Claude’s huge gait.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CLAUDE
dialogues.text: You’1l be my apprentice. You'll live with me and I’1l show you how to take care of them clocks. (Takes a swig from a flask) I’m getting too old to be climbing through them tunnels. They turn a corner. And ahead of them... The Train Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Claude and Hugo enter the secret apartment. It is filthy and rank. Dickensian. Hugo sets down the Automaton. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CLAUDE
dialogues.text: They built these apartments for them who ran the station, years ago. Everyone’s forgotten they’re here. You sleep in the corner. Uncle Claude plops down. Drinks.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Get some sleep. We start work at five.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What about school?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CLAUDE
dialogues.text: You're finished with school. There won't be time for that once you're in them walls ... You should thank me.  20. Uncle Claude clears his throat. Takes a drink. Looks away Hugo carries the Automaton to his corner. He sits. Dazed. Absolutely forlorn. Then he pulls the sheet off the Automaton. He looks into the Automaton’s face. His only friend. They sit together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funeral tableau. Hugo and Uncle Claude at the grave site. Uncle Claude dri from his flask. Hugo bows his head. Tears beginning to fall. Color gradually returns as we leave the past and return t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo sits, looking at the Automaton. Alone. Despondent. We fade to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo peers out from behind an air vent. Waiting. Watching. Madame Emilie is opening her little cafe. Her dachshund hovers protectively. Monsieur Frick approaches cautiously. Bows gallantly and offers her a newspaper from his kiosk. Madame Emilie is charmed. The dachshund attacks this time! It chases Monsi Frick away. Madame Emilie follows in horror.  21. Hugo seizes his opportunity-- He scrambles quickly from the air vent-- Races to the cafe-- Grabs a croissant and bottle of milk-- Runs off-- Disappearing into the crowd of morning commuters. INT. TRAIN STATION -- GRAND HALL —- MORNING Hugo moves through the grown up world, eating the croissa No one notices him. He sees the imposing Station Inspector and the ferocious Maximilian approaching! Hugo moves next to a woman. Falls into step. Acts like he son. She doesn’t notice. The Station Inspector passes. Hugo continues on. But Maximilian stops. Turns. Sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: What is it? He looks. Sees nothing.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: We shall be alert, my friend ... We shall be ... vigilant. He and Maximilian go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is opening the Toy Booth. Hugo stands silently behind him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I thought I might see you today.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I need my notebook.  22.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Why do you need it so badly?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: To help me ... fix something.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: What? Hugo doesn’t answer. Georges hands Hugo a handkerchief tied up into a bundle. unties it. Ashes. It is filled with ashes. Burned paper. Hugo looks at the ashes. Horror and disbelief. Tears stin his eyes. He can’t breathe. The ashes fall... Cascade and swirl delicately down... Over Hugo’s shoes... To the floor. Hugo looks up at Georges. He is shocked to see there are tears in Georges’ eyes as well.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Go away ... Please just go away. Hugo wipes his eyes with his dirty, ashen hands, leaving black smudges on his face. He backs away. Then he turns and runs off. Tears flowing freely now. He races around a corner and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Bang! He runs right into Isabelle. She was hiding, waiting for  23.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Sorry -- I--

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I saw. Are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hold still. She uses her handkerchief to dry his eyes and clean his f as:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with crying. Sidney Carton cries. And Heathcliff too. In books they’re crying all the time.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (grabs handkerchief) I can do it!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you. It’s terribly important. But not here. We’re too ... exposed. She dramatically grabs his hand and pulls him off. INT. TRAIN STATION -- GRAND HALL —- MORNING Hugo continues to clean his face as they move through a different part of the station. She is carrying a book.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Only to the most wonderful place on earth! Neverland and Oz and Treasure Island all wrapped up into one. They are approaching Monsieur Rouleau. He is at work on h Surrealist painting.  24.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Monsieur Rouleau.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Morning. She stops and looks at the abstract painting.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s coming along marvelously!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: It’s the station ... How I see it anyway ... Do you like it? Hugo looks at the painting. Takes it seriously. Isabelle appreciates this.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You know, I think I do ... Yes, I like it very much. Monsieur Rouleau is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: We have to go ... Well done, Monsieur Rouleau! Hugo and Isabelle go.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: He’s a Surrealist.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: That’s a kind of painter.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I know what a Surrealist is. I’m not an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Ah, here we are! Ahead of them... Her secret realm ... Wonderland and Oz and Treasure Islan all wrapped up into one...  25. A used bookstore. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little bell jangles when they enter. MONSIEUR LABISSE, the shop owner, is perched high on a st at the front of the store like the Caterpillar from ALICE WONDERLAND, peering over a stack of dusty books. He is a slight, sad sort of man. He brightens when he see Isabelle. But he is extremely suspicious of Hugo.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Good morning, Monsieur Labisse, may I present Monsieur Hugo Cabret, a very old and dear boon companion.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE
dialogues.text: (bows ) Monsieur Cabret.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (handing him book) Thank you for this. I think I’m halfway in love with David Copperfield ... Photography?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE
dialogues.text: (points) Back corner left, top shelf.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Monsieur Labisse watches them go. Hugo’s dirty clothes an long hair convince him he must be a shoplifter -- or wors Isabelle leads Hugo deeper into the store. It is a world of books. Stacked in every direction. To th ceiling. Rivers of books. Mountains of books. Gloriously cluttered.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Listen, what’s so important?  26.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Papa Georges still has your notebook. He didn’t burn it. That was all a trick.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Why? She climbs a ladder in search of a book:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The notebook made him very upset. He and Mama Jeanne stayed up late talking about it. I think he was crying. Hugo thinks about this. How strange.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: It’s a mystery.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Why are you helping me?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Because this might be an adventure! I’ve never had one, outside of books. She grabs a book. Comes back down the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I think we should be very ... clandestine.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: By the way, my name’s Isabelle ... Do you want a book? Monsieur Labisse lets me borrow them. I could get one for you.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (horrified) Don’t you like books?!  27.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No, I do ... My father and I used to read Jules Verne together... He stops. She senses his strong emotion. Respects it. They move to Monsieur Labisse at the front counter.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (xe: book) May I?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE
dialogues.text: Of course. Good day, Isabelle. Monsieur Labisse watches Hugo with suspicion as they leav the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move through the bustling station.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: How do I get my notebook back?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I think you should stand up to him. He'll respect that ... Don’t tell him we talked. I’1l help you if I can ... Be steadfast! She disappears into the crowd. He watches her go. Be steadfast? What a peculiar girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is sitting at the counter. Evenly staring at something. He aimlessly cuts and re-cuts a deck of cards with one ha as he stares. We finally see what he is staring at... Hugo stands there on the other side of the counter. Stari back at him. Steadfast.  It is like a showdown. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you burned my notebook.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: You don’t? ... Well, maybe I did and maybe I didn’t. You’1l never know, will you? Hugo holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Shall I call the Station Inspector? Hugo holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Go ... away. Hugo holds his ground. Georges glares at him. Hugo glares back. A long beat. Gunfighters. Neither blinks. Then... Georges slowly reaches under the counter... He pulls something out... Something covered in a handkerchief... He sets it on the counter... 28. With the panache of a magician, he pulls off the handkerc to reveal... The toy mouse that Hugo broke earlier.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Fix it. Hugo looks at him.  29.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I said, fix it.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I need my tools. Georges pulls out a canister of tiny screwdrivers, pliers files and hammers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I know you’ve been stealing parts from the shop ... Might as well use those you haven’t stolen yet. Hugo looks at the broken toy mouse. Then at Georges.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: If I fix it, do I get my notebook?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: We'll see. A challenge. Hugo starts to work. He uses the tiny tools ... hammering ... screwing ... adjusting ... tinkering... Georges watches. Hugo fixes the spring ... fits the key ... hammers the body... Finally he sets the toy mouse down on the counter. Georges looks at it. He winds it. The toy mouse skitters playfully across the counter. Georges is impressed, tries not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Give me my notebook.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: You've got a bit of talent. But you'll have to prove there’s more to you than being a thief ... You can earn your notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Come to the booth everyday. I'll decide how long you must work for each item you stole, and it will be up to me to decide when you have earned your notebook, if ever.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I already have a job.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Thief is not a job, boy.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I have another job, but I’1l come when I can.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: You begin tomorrow. Go away.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I’1l begin now. Hugo bravely goes into the booth and gets a broom. Starts sweeping up. Georges watches him. 30. Across the station, a little DANCE BAND is starting up at Madame Emilie’s cafe. A few couples dance. An afternoon tea dance. A lovely, bygone image. Couples dancing under the massive iron ribs of the great train station. The music echoes throughout the Grand Hall. The music from the band takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance band music as... --. Hugo works at the Toy Booth. Across the booth, does a card trick. Hugo watches the trick closely. notices. Georges Georges  31. .-. Isabelle and Hugo walk through the bookstore, chattin Monsieur Labisse eyes Hugo with suspicion. -.. Georges teaches Hugo how to do the card trick. .-. Hugo demonstrates the card trick to the Automaton. ... Hugo repairs a broken toy in the booth. Isabelle is there, chatting to him. He ducks away when the Station Inspector and Maximilian pass. She is intrigued. -.. Georges watches Hugo demonstrate the card trick to a customer. He hides a smile. .-. Hugo works on the Automaton. It looks done: polished, cleaned, beautiful and ready. But for one thing. We now s that there is HEART-SHAPED KEYHOLE in the back. --. Hugo tries a bit of bent metal in the keyhole. Doesn’ fit. He adds it to a collection of scavenged items he has tried. Nothing fits. .--. Isabelle and Hugo playfully dance to the band at the with other couples. -.. Georges watches them dance. Content. ... The band dance ends the song with a flourish. Hugo bo to Isabelle. She laughs. The montage ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo is waiting for Isabelle outside the book shop. He sees the Station Inspector and Maximilian cutting thro the crowd. Hugo ducks around a corner and watches nervous But the Station Inspector has another quarry today. A young STREET KID, around Hugo’s age, is loitering near another shop. The Station Inspector stalks him and then sweeps down lik bird of prey. The Street Kid makes a move to bolt-- But the Station Inspector releases Maximilian, who leaps, crouches and snarls in front of the terrified Kid-- The Station Inspector grabs the Kid brutally. Shakes him.  32.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Where are you parents?! Answer me!

dialogues.speaker: STREET KID
dialogues.text: (terrified) Got none. Without another word, the Station Inspector drags him awa his leg brace squeaking ominously. Maximilian loping afte them. Hugo darts into an air vent. INT. TRAIN STATION -- NARROW PASSAGE/INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - Hugo is in a cramped passage that overlooks the Station Inspector's office, peering through a clock face. The Street Kid is in a tiny, awful cell. He is sobbing. Maximilian sits alert, glaring in at the Kid. The Station Inspector is oiling his leg brace as he talks the phone:

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (on phone) +». yes, another one. Useless waste of an orphan by the looks of it. Come get it. Suddenly-- Maximilian turns. Looks toward Hugo, ears perked. Hugo sinks back into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo watches through a clock face. He sees the Station Inspector dragging the Street Kid thr the doors of the station and throwing him into a police truck. The truck roars off. The Station Inspector comes back inside. He stands looking over his domain. Maximilian at his side Imperious. Hugo disappears back into the tunnels.  33. We linger for a moment with the Station Inspector. His ey scan the terminal. Then he stops. He watches LISETTE. A beautiful and shy girl who runs a little flower stall. She’s organizing bunches of flowers. They surround her: an explosion of vibrant color in the terminal. The Station Inspector gazes at her. He’s besotted, has be for a while. He gets up his nerve ... Puts on an awkward smile ... He begins to approach... But then his leg brace squeaks sharply. It echoes through terminal. He stops. Embarrassed. He gives up. Moves off with Maximilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo and Isabelle move through the bookstore.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: ++. I’m still looking for your notebook. I have to be very circumspect. She loves the word.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You better not look inside.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: If I find it I should be able to look inside it.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Then don’t look for it!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I’m trying to help. Why are you being so mean? His heart sinks.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Just ... Promise me you won’t open it.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Fine. To Hugo she suddenly looks very grown up. She is disappoi  34. They wander deeper into the store. Monsieur Labisse, perched on his high stool, keeps an war eye on Hugo. Hugo picks up a copy of ROBIN HOOD, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I saw this movie! With Douglas Fairbanks. Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen a movie.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Isn’t it appalling?!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You’ve never seen a movie? Not ever?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Papa Georges won’t let me. He’s very strict about it.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (excited) I love movies! My father always took me for my birthday. Hugo is surprised he suddenly spoke about his father. He not regret it though. They wander through the teetering piles of books in silen

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Is your father dead?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t want to talk about it. A beat. She takes his hand for a quick moment, then releases it. A gesture of support. Friendship. They continue strolling. Hugo stops. An idea. He looks at her.  35.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Isabelle ... Do you want to have an adventure? Her eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the suggestion of Paris. A movie theatre facade. An Art Deco marquee. A green neon sign: Silent Movie Festival. Isabelle and Hugo stand looking up at the theatre. She looks at him. Beams. He nods his head and nonchalantly leads her down an alley next to the theatre...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move down the alley ... passing a series of fading m posters ... Keaton ... Lon Chaney ... Doug Fairbanks... He stops at a side door and begins to deftly pick the loc with one of his tools.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: We could get into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: That’s how you know it’s an adventure. Click. He opens the door and peeks in. Coast is clear. He looks at her. Yes or no? She’s game. They sneak in. INT. MOVIE THEATRE -— DAY The flickering light above.  36. The glowing screen. Iridescent. Hugo and Isabelle are sitting at the back. The famous Harold Lloyd film SAFETY LAST is playing. Isabelle’s eyes are wide. She’s transported. The magic of motion pictures. She’s never seen one before. Life captured on the screen. Living, moving history. The iridescent glow from the screen illuminates her face. Hugo glances to her. Her enchantment touches him. He smiles. The light flickers above them. Time passes... It's the climax of SAFETY LAST. Isabelle is wrapped up in the movie. Can barely watch. Can barely breathe. Harold Lloyd is climbing dangerously around the outside o the skyscraper. Acrobatic stunts still hair-raising after these years. Harold Lloyd grabs the big clock face. It springs open--! Isabelle grabs Hugo’s arm in horror--! Hugo looks at her. Amused. Harold Lloyd clings to the hands of the clock and then continues to climb around the building. Then... From the darkness behind Hugo and Isabelle... Two huge white hands slowly descend...  37. Like the Frankenstein Monster's mitts... Grabbing them on the shoulder... They jump! The THEATRE MANAGER looms over them.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: How did you two rats get in here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Manager dumps them outside.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRE MANAGER
dialogues.text: And I better not see you in here again! He closes the doors. Hugo and Isabelle laugh and run off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is chilly. Fog. Hugo and Isabelle walk home along the Seine. The silhouette of bridges. The sound of lapping water. Th shape of boats moving past. Radio music from a houseboat. Hugo tightrope walks along the edge of the bank, like Har Lloyd on a ledge from SAFETY LAST.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t Papa Georges let you go to the movies?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He never said. I bet my parents would have let me. I’m sure they were very aesthetic.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What happened to them?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: They died when I was a baby. Papa Georges and Mama Jeanne are my godparents, so they took me in. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're very nice about most everything, except the movies.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: My father took me to the movies all the time. We saw Tom Mix and Lon Chaney. But Douglas Fairbanks was my favorite. Hugo sword fights along the bank for a moment. A beat as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What was he like?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: He loved the movies ... Ever since he was a kid and the movies were new. He told me about the first one he ever saw. He went into a dark room and on a white screen he saw a rocket fly into the eye of the man in the moon. (smiles) He said it was like seeing his dreams in the middle of the day. A beat as they walk. He speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: The movies were our special place. It was just us ... We’d go in and watch something ... and for a little while we didn’t miss my mom so much. She’s touched by his honesty.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: You think about him a lot.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: All the time. A beat as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Who looks after you?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: My uncle was supposed to ... But he started going away a lot. Drinking. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staying out all night ... One day he didn’t come back.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: So you’re all alone?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Not completely. A beat as they walk. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hugo ... Where do you live? He stops. Looks at her. Should he tell her? Should he trust her? Yes. He points.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: There. She looks... Across the river... The Train Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo and Isabelle move through the crowd. She is incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: --. My uncle taught me how to run the clocks. So I just keep on doing it ... Maybe he’1ll come back one day, but I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: But ... Aren’t you afraid someone will find out? 39.  40.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Not as long as the clocks keep on working and no one sees me.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What do you do for money?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Don’t need any. A beat as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Can I see it?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Where you live! In the walls.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe? Hugo suddenly sees... The Station Inspector and Maximilian... Walking right toward them...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Act natural.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Just keep walking. Act natural.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (perplexed) How am I acting now? Then she sees the Station Inspector and Maximilian. She understands. They put on an elaborate show of “acting natural” as they walk toward the Station Inspector. They pass him.  A sigh of relief. But... The Station Inspector stops. 4l. Turns. His leg brace squeaks like a rifle shot.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Hey! You two. Hugo and Isabelle freeze.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Come ... here. Hugo is about to bolt. Isabelle sees it in his eyes. With a look, she cautions him against it. She will handle this another way. She drags him back to the Station Inspector. sweetest face:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Good day, Monsieur!

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (icy) Where are your parents?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I work with my Papa Georges at the Toy Booth, surely you’ve seen me there. And this is my cousin from the country, Hugo. (Whispers) You’1l have to forgive him, he’s a little simple-minded. Doltish, really. Poor thing. The Station Inspector leans in. Peers closely at Hugo. Hugo gives him a simple-minded look. Maximilian noses right up to Hugo. Sniffing. A low growl. Puts on her  42.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: It seems Maximilian disapproves of you, little creature ... Why would he disapprove of you?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I... don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (to the rescue) Perhaps he smells my cat?! Christina Rossetti’s her name, after the poetess! Would you like me to recite? “My heart is like a singing bird/Whose nest is in a watered shoot--!”

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: All right, all right ... Go on then -.. But remember, in my terminal children are not permitted to run amok ... Not ever. He gives them a last chilling glare and goes. They see hi into this office, shut the door. They’re free of him for moment. Hugo looks at Isabelle.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Doltish?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: It worked didn’t it? They continue on.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Now since I just saved your life how about letting me see your covert lair?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: My what?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Where you live in the walls!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I can’t understand what you’re saying half the time.  43.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: That's because I am so gigantically literate.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I’1l tell you what ... I’11 let you see my “covert lair” if you do one thing...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You have to...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Catch me! And he is off like a shot-- Isabelle laughs and pursues-- A wild chase through the station. It is nice to see Hugo enjoying himself. His usually sobe face is smiling. His serious personality gives way to sim play. He’s just a kid now. Having fun with his friend. Hugo tears through the station... Past the cafe... Leaping over Madame Emilie’s yapping dachshund... Careening around Monsieur Rouleau’s easel... Barreling through the terminal... Isabelle follows. Laughing. This is all from a child’s perspective. We cut past tower adults. Weaving in and out. Diving under platform gates. Scrambling over benches. And at top speed. Sliding and _ skidding wildly on the polished floors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefree. Then Hugo diverts quickly through a door into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo sweeps past towers of luggage-- He jumps and climbs over a cart piled high with luggage a steamer trunks-- Isabelle follows gamely, laughing, bouncing after him-- They slam through a door to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly-- A tight corridor. Scores of passengers moving swiftly. A great crowd. Too many. Hugo and Isabelle are unexpectedly caught in the mob of passengers. The passengers are hurrying. Late. In a rush. Too many big people pushing them back and forth, crowding them, jostling them. Isabelle trips! She falls. Amidst the pounding crush of feet. Scary. Hugo turns. His face. Concern. He pushes back. Reaches for her. His hand stretches out. She takes his hand. Her face.  Grateful. He pulls her up to safety. The crowd thins out around them. But he is staring at something, amazed. 45. In the action, a necklace has emerged from her collar. A on a piece of string. A distinctive heart-shaped key.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Where did you get that?!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: None of your business. She tucks the key away.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I need it.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I just need it.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Not unless you tell me why. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo leads her through the tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: This is marvelous! ... I feel like Jean Valjean!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I used to imagine I was the Phantom of the Opera. Like in the movie.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: It was a book too. You know sometimes things are books before they’re movies! He leads her through the iron door to...  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo lights some candles. She takes the apartment in. The cramped quarters. The cha of tools and machine parts hanging everywhere. She loves

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Oh, this is superlative! Hugo pulls a sheet off the Automaton. She is instantly captivated by the wonderful machine.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: It’s an automaton ... My father was fixing it before he died.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Why would my key fit your father’s machine? ... That doesn’t make any sense. They look at the Automaton for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: He looks sad.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I think he’s just waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: To work again. To do what he’s supposed to do.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What happens when you wind him up?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She takes off her necklace. Hands it to him. He fills the Automaton’s little inkwell with ink. He puts a fresh piece of paper on the little writing desk  47. It’s ready. Hugo pauses.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I know it’s silly but ... I think it’s going to be a message from my father.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go? He shakes his head. A beat. Then he carefully inserts the key. And winds the Automaton. Steps back. The world hangs in suspense. Nothing happens. He looks at her. She doesn’t know what to say. He looks back at the Automaton. Nothing. But... Then we go... INSIDE the Automaton’s body: Things begins to move... A cascade of perfect movements, with hundreds of brillian calibrated actions... A spring connects to a series of gears... The gears extend down to the base of the figure and turn brass disks...  48. Two little hammers come down and trail along the edges of disks... The little hammers translate motion back up through a ser of rods... The rods silently turn other intricate mechanisms in the figure’s shoulder and neck... The shoulder gears move... Engaging the elbow... Setting off a chain reaction of movements down to the wrist... And finally... The hand. QUTSIDE again: Hugo and Isabelle watch. The Automaton’s hand moves slightly. Just a twitch. They gasp. Hugo and Isabelle lean forward, wide-eyed with wonder. The miniature hand begins, very cautiously, to move. Hugo and Isabelle hold their breath. The Automaton dips the pen into the ink and begins to wri It draws a small line. The hand moves. Another small line The hand moves. Another small line. Hugo and Isabelle lean closer. The Automaton continues to move. Dip the pen. Draw a line Move. Draw a line. Dip the pen. Move. Draw a line. But it is meaningless. A series of scratches and lines without order. Nothing. Hugo stares. His heart sinking.  49. Then the Automaton stops. Finished. Hugo is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What an idiot -- Thinking I could fix it--

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hugo-—

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: It’s broken. It’ll always be broken! Anguish beyond tears. She doesn’t know what to do. She goes to him. Trying to comfort.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hugo ... You can still--

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You don’t understand. I thought if I could fix it ... I wouldn’t be so alone. He buries his head in his hands. A long beat. Then she notices something. The Automaton is moving again.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Hugo ... Hugo, look -- look! He glances up.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: It’s not done! It’s not done! They rush back to the Automaton. It is moving more quickly now. All the gears and wheels spinning perfectly. Draw-move-ink-draw-move. Hugo realizes:  50.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: It’s not writing ... It’s drawing! Indeed it is. Faster and faster. A blur of ink. Lines forming together. Shading and cross-hatching. Draw-move-draw-move-ink-draw- draw. An image begins to emerge. We don’t see it entirely. We see bits and pieces. Something familiar about it. Hugo and Isabelle stare. Finally the Automaton stops. It waits. Pen poised. Hugo and Isabelle exchange a glance. And we finally see the image in full... And recognize it instantly... A TRIP TO THE MOON. The round face of the man in the moon. Rocket protruding his right eye. Hugo’s father’s favorite movie. The very image he told Hu about. Hugo is trembling. Suddenly-- The Automaton starts moving again--! Hugo and Isabelle jump--! The Automaton dips the pen and moves its hand into positi And signs the drawing: “Georges Melies.” A flourish under the signature and then the Automaton is done.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: “Georges Melies” ... That’s Papa Georges’ name! Why did your father’s machine sign Papa Georges’ name?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: And why does my key fit it? Hugo shakes his head. He just looks at the Automaton. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Thank you. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: It was a message from my father ... Now we have to figure it out. She is delighted. A mystery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is sinking. Hugo and Isabelle approach the apartment building. Hugo, who has watched it so often from outside, hesitates going in.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Come on. They enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impoverished gentility. A few small rooms. Neatly kept. Old furniture. Fading wallpaper. MAMA JEANNE, Georges’ wife, is sewing in a corner. She we heavy reading glasses. She is a handsome older woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabelle and Hugo enter.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Isabelle...?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (kisses her) 52. Mama Jeanne, we have to talk to you --. This is Hugo Cabret.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Good evening, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Very good manners for a thief.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I’m not a thief. Jeanne considers him coolly over her glasses. Removes the

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: What’s going on, Isabelle?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (excited) Oh, well, it’s a terribly long story, filled with circumlocutions! It all began several weeks ago when I was... Hugo stops her:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Wait. He pulls something from inside his coat. A piece of paper. Folded over. He hands it to Mama Jeanne. She unfolds it. It is the picture the Automaton drew. The TO THE MOON. She stares down at it. A complex range of emotions pass over her --. nostalgia ... sadness ... When she looks up at them there are tears Isabelle is struck by the sight. image from A TRIP features ... shock in her eyes.  53.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Children ... What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Mama Jeanne...? Mama Jeanne dries her eyes with a little handkerchief. Isabelle finds there are tears in her eyes as well. Hugo sees Isabelle’s tears. Feels awful.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You’11 call me a liar.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: No, child.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: A mechanical man drew it.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: You have him?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: My father found him in a museum. No one wanted him. We fixed him.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: But it needed ... (She realizes. Looks at Isabelle. ) My key. Isabelle removes the key.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: The key I gave you... A beat as it all sinks in. Then she stands. She hands the drawing back to Hugo.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Please, take it away. We can’t dredge up the past now. And whatever happens, don’t let Papa Georges see it.  54.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Please tell us what’s going on! She begins to lead Hugo to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: It’s no business of yours. You must forget all this. Hugo stops. Holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: We worked hard to fix it, my father and me, and ... it’s all I have left of him ... I need to know what it means. A beat. Mama Jeanne looks at him. Moved by his passion and need. She looks at him seriously. Speaks with great compassion.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: There are things you are too young to understand ... You should not yet know such sadness. Then... They hear someone climbing up the stairs to the apartment

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: It’s Papa Georges!

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: He can’t know you’re here. This way... She quickly leads them through the apartment to the maste bedroom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama Jeanne hurries them in:

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Just keep quiet. I’1l find a way to get him out of the apartment. Not a noise from either of you.  55. She inadvertently glances toward a large armoire. Hugo an Isabelle both notice. Then she quickly goes. Shutting the door. A long beat. Hugo and Isabelle look at each other. They hear the muffled sounds of Mama Jeanne and Georges talking in another room. Whispers:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: She looked at the armoire.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I already searched it when I was looking for your notebook.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I’‘1l look again. You stand guard!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Splendid! Hugo opens the armoire and searches through it. Isabelle, meanwhile, goes to the door. Peeks through the keyhole. Through the keyhole: Georges and Jeanne are across the apartment, in the kitchen. She is pouring coffee. She ste a nervous glance to the bedroom door. Hugo rifles through the armoire. Clothes. Sheets. No clue No treasure. Nothing. Hugo steps back, studies the outside of the tall armoire. He notices something: A decorative panel at the very top of the armoire has two thin parallel cracks in it.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Look!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: We have to investigate! He carries a chair to the armoire.  56.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Let me, I’m taller. She climbs up on the chair and examines the decorative pa She has to stand on her tiptoes to reach it. He makes a gesture for her to knock on it. She does so. It sounds hollow. They are both excited. She carefully grips the edges of the decorative panel. Sh pulls. She pulls again. The panel comes off in her hands! Revealing... A hidden compartment at the top of the armoire! A large box is inside the compartment. Isabelle hands down the panel to Hugo. Then she begins to pull the box out. But it is heavy. She struggles a bit. He holds the chair steady. She almost has the box out now... But it is ungainly, she was unprepared for the weight, an she is still balancing on her tiptoes... As she pulls the box out... She loses her balance... The chair lurches... She almost falls... But miraculously gets her balance... Shoots a relieved glance down to Hugo... But... Then a leg of the chair SNAPS--! She falls-- Shrieks-- Hugo catches her--  57. The box falls-- CRASHES to the floor-- SMASHING open-- Sending up a cyclone of paper-- Hundreds of pieces of paper of every shape and size scatt across the floor and fly through the air-- Hugo and Isabelle are surrounded by a tornado of paper, i swirls around them-- On the paper-- Wonderful drawings. Fanciful and imaginative. Dragons and devils. Spaceships and submarines. Fairies and fish. Elaborate landscapes of fantasy... One of the drawings seems to slow as it whirls past Hugo. The man in the moon, a rocket protruding from his right eye... The swirling papers finally descend to earth... Revealing... Georges. Standing in the doorway. Mama Jeanne behind him. Georges looks at the carpet of drawings spread out before him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: (whispers) Back from the dead ... His quiet anguish gives way to anger-- He wades into the drawings-- Grabbing handfuls-- Tearing them up-- Shredding them violently-- Flinging them away-- Mama Jeanne grabs him:  58.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Stop it, Georges! Stop! This is your work!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: My work?! -- What am I? Nothing but a penniless merchant! A broken windup toy! He spins on Hugo in fury:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I trusted you -- and this is how you thank me?! You cruel -- cruel-- Suddenly he can’t speak-- Something's wrong -- he gulps for air-- Mama Jeanne sits him on the bed. He is exhausted, gasping breath. His sad eyes gaze over the chaos of drawings. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: An empty box, an old rocket, a lost monster ... nothing, nothing, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Georges ... I’m so sorry... Isabelle takes Hugo’s arm and gently pulls him out. He glances back. Sees Mama Jeanne tenderly holding her disconsolate husban Hugo is haunted by the poignant image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening. Street lamps are coming on, illuminate the scene Isabelle is at the front door. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I should go back.  59.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Okay. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen him cry before. Hugo takes her hand. A comforting gesture of friendship. She acknowledges it. A faint smile. She starts to close the door. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Thank you for the movie today ... It was a gift. She shuts the door. Hugo walks down the street. He stops under the street lamp for a moment. Gazing back at the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo enters. Deep in thought. Head down. He’s not looking and accidentally bumps right into-- The frosty Monsieur Labisse! Labisse drops a few books he carrying. Hugo quickly picks them up:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry, sir! He notices one of the books is the ROBIN HOOD he was look at before. He smiles when he sees it.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE
dialogues.text: You know that volume?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I used to read it with my father...

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE
dialogues.text: Hm ... It was intended for my godson. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now I think it is intended for you. (slight formal bow) Monsieur Cabret. Labisse goes, leaving Hugo with the book. Hugo is shocked his unexpected act of kindness. A voice:

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Things aren't always what they seem. Hugo turns. Monsieur Rouleau is working on his painting nearby. Hugo goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Why would he give it to me?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Because you needed it. Hugo looks at Monsieur Rouleau’s Surrealist painting. It like Magritte or Dali. But the images echo Hugo’s story. robot. A train. A clock...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I recognize the clock. But it’s different.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Sitting here, day after day, I watch things. I watch them change in the light. A clock becomes a wheel becomes a train becomes a rocket becomes a robot ... It’s like a story.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: How does it end?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The story’s not over yet. There’s something gently magical and mad about Monsieur Rouleau, touched and touching. He mixes some paint on his palette.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: But it’ll be surprising.  61.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Because things aren't always what they seem?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Well, look around you ... Not all clocks run forever ... not all little boys live in houses ... and not all messages are written on paper. Hugo is struck by his words.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Quick, behind the canvas! Hugo sees the Station Inspector approaching. He ducks beh Monsieur Rouleau’s large canvas. The Station Inspector arrives.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Monsieur Artiste. How goes the painting? May I look?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: (stops him) Not ready yet. Soon ... Things must happen at the opportune moment. The Station Inspector looks across the terminal to the lo Lisette at her flower stall. The object of his affection. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: If we only knew when that moment was...

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: For the heart, there is only now, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: Of course! Go say hello to her ... Go on, give me your best smile. The Station Inspector tries out his best and brightest sm sort of a pained grimace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh ... Radiant! The Station Inspector is encouraged. He steels walks away toward Lisette. Hugo emerges from hiding.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir ... Your painting is going to be magnificent. Hugo scurries off. Monsieur Rouleau watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR ROULEAU
dialogues.text: So is yours. Meanwhile... 62. himself and The Station Inspector heads toward Lisette at the flower stall. She’s arranging a breathtaking bunch of like a vision from Monet. He freshens his maladroit smile and “casually”

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle Lisette, a very gracious good evening to you.

dialogues.speaker: LISETTE
dialogues.text: (shy) Monsieur Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Hm. Yes ... Those are lovely posies there.

dialogues.speaker: LISETTE
dialogues.text: They're from Gourdon. They come in on the overnight train.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Ah, Gourdon. Splendid country that. All the ... cows and such ... Do they have a smell? blue irises, arrives. He leans in to sniff the irises. This causes his leg brac squeak awkwardly. He stiffens. She glances to his brace. He sees her glance. A moment between them.  He nods stiffly. Turns to go. Walks a few steps. But then he stops ... No. He will not be ashamed returns to her.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You see I was injured in the war. It will never heal ... Good evening to you, Mademoiselle. He turns to go. But...

dialogues.speaker: LISETTE
dialogues.text: I lost my brother.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: LISETTE
dialogues.text: Verdun. 63. --. He His eyes are sympathetic. He was there. He knows. A beat. Neither is sure what to do. How to proceed. Then she smiles shyly, snaps off a blossom, and tucks it his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: LISETTE
dialogues.text: Good evening, Monsieur Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (bows ) Good evening, Mademoiselle Lisette. He goes. His leg brace squeaking proudly. And we fade to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide boulevard. Fine motorcars. Magisterial buildings. A part of Paris we have not seen before. Wealth privilege. and  64. Hugo and Isabelle look particularly small standing in fro of the most august building on the street: The French Fil Academy. Two great stone lions flank the entrance. The lions gaze balefully at them, as if annoyed at their presumption. They summon their courage and enter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo and Isabelle’s heels click as they cross an enormous marble void to the reception desk. The RECEPTIONIST -- a stern dragon of a woman -- watches their approach as balefully as did the lions outside. They finally reach her.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Madame-- She stops -- her voice echoes in the massive chamber -- continues more quietly:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, we would like to use the library. She looks them up and down.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You’re too small and too dirty. Goodbye. She returns to her paperwork. They stand for a moment. Isabelle starts to go. Hugo stops her. He addresses the dragon receptionist:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I thought the library was open to all Frenchmen.  65.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Not small and dirty ones.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: In that case ... (clears his throat nervously) I would like to see your superior. She looks at him. Daggers.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: What kind of dreadful little Jacobin are you?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: The kind that wants to use the library. He holds his ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo and Isabelle move through a lovely library. Two stories. Shining brass fixtures and rich wooden shelv Neats rows of books. They go to the circulation desk. The bored STUDENT mannin the desk doesn’t even glance up from his book.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, we’re looking for a book about very early movies.

dialogues.speaker: BORED STUDENT
dialogues.text: (points without looking) Rene Tabard. THE INVENTION OF DREAMS. Row Four. Section Three. Top shelf.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Much obliged. What are you reading? Hugo hauls her away. They move through the stacks to find Row Four, Section Th They pull down a large book from the top shelf. They go to a library table and look at the book: THE INVENTION OF DREAMS: THE STORY OF THE FIRST MOVIES by Rene Tabard.  66. Hugo runs his hands over the cover. He glances to Isabelle. This could be it. The answer to their quest. He opens the book. They begin to read:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “In 1895, one of the very first films ever shown was called A TRAIN ARRIVES IN THE STATION, which showed nothing more than a train coming into a station...” We see the little film of the train steaming into the station.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “But when the train came speeding toward the screen, the audience screamed because they thought they were in danger of being run over. No one had ever seen anything like it before.” Hugo smiles to her:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No one had ever seen anything like it before. They turn the page... And we go with them... INTO THE BOOK... Flickering images from the very first movies... Fragile fragments of life captured forever... A stream of factory workers leaving work ... Two Edison technicians dancing ... Skyscrapers in New York ... Londo street scene ... a boxing match ...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “What began as a sideshow novelty soon grew into something more as the first filmmakers discovered they could use the new medium to tell stories...”  67. And now we see storytelling and narrative replacing the quaint real life images... Edison's THE KISS ... THE GREAT TRAIN ROBBERY ... THE CAB OF DR. CALIGARI ... INTOLERANCE ... Buster Keaton ... Lou Brooks ... William S. Hart ... Doug Fairbanks ... Jean Renoir... The splendid, magical, romantic, lost world of silent mov flickers past... And then... The culmination of the whole sequence... We end at one iconic image... Glowing with light... A TRIP TO THE MOON. The man in the moon with a rocket protruding from his eye Hugo and Isabelle stare at the image. They share an excited glance.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (reads ) “The filmmaker Georges Melies was among the first to realized that film had the power to capture dreams...”

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (reads ) “This great pioneer of early cinema died during the Great War--”

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Died...?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (reads ) “Died during the Great War.” They stop. Stunned. Unbeknownst to them, a tall and imposing figure has been looming over them. Observing. PROFESSOR RENE TABARD is a formidable presence. Stern and uncompromising.  68.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: You're interested in Melies? The kids jump -- slam the book shut almost guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Yes, uh--

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: It’s allowed.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Is it? A long, cool, appraising stare. Then Hugo realizes something -- he nudges Isabelle -- the photo on the back of the book shows the author: Rene Tabard. The same man who is standing before them.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Come with me. INT. FILM ACADEMY -- TABARD’S OFFICE - DAY A door opens into ... the world of Georges Melies. Professor Tabard’s office is something of a shrine to Mel Tattered old movie posters, film stills and handbills for magic shows line the walls. Mountains of books, photographs and archival records. Als few props and costume pieces lovingly preserved. Tabard shows Hugo and Isabelle some of the photographs an artifacts:

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Here he is at work in his studio -.. And this is a handbill advertising his stage act ... And this is one of his actual cameras!

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Why do you have all this?

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Your godfather is a passion of mine. He was a great filmmaker.  69.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (looking at a photo) He was a magician? They look at a photo of showing a YOUNG GEORGES on a stag doing a magic trick:

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Yes, he began on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: How did he start making movies?

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: No one really knows. Hugo has been studying the old photographs and Daguerreotypes. Something special strikes him about them.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Look how happy he is... Indeed, the joy and passion on Young Georges’ face is a marked difference to the moody old man we know. Isabelle turns to Tabard with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Professor Tabard ... Would you like to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Oh, but you see, I have met him. He smiles. The color fades as we go into Tabard’s memory. As with Hugo’s flashback earlier, this has the quality of SILENT FILM. The flickering, glowing luminescence of earl movies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the country, outside Paris. YOUNG TABARD is with his Brother. Young Tabard, around te is staring at something, awed at what he is seeing.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My brother worked as a carpenter building sets for Melies. One day he took me to visit the studio... We see what Young Tabard has been gazing at:  70. George Melies’ film studio. The studio is an absolutely astounding sight. A great greenhouse-like collection of glass rooms. A soaring cast of glass:

dialogues.speaker: TABARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was like something out of a dream. The whole building was made of glass ... In reality this was to let in all the sunlight necessary for filming, but to my eyes it was nothing short of an enchanted castle ... a palace made of glass... Young Tabard and his Brother go into the studio...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dragon! A great mechanical puppet, writhing and attacking, jaws snapping, articulated by puppeteers. They’re trying to ge to work for the shot: a battle with some knights. Young Tabard is engulfed in the filming of one of Georges movies. It’s a joyous chaos of wildly dressed performers, fantastic sets, explosive special effects, technicians, filmmakers. In the background we see flats and set pieces from other Melies movies: moons, suns, monsters, great fish, castles And at the camera ... his back to us ... is YOUNG GEORGES himself.
