Lining up the shot. Fiddling with the camera. Young Tabard sits quietly in a corner and watches as the technicians try to get the dragon to work properly. Young Georges finally turns from the camera and we see hi face ... Vital. Alive. Happy ... A marvelous twinkle in h eye. He glances over to Young Tabard. Sees the enchanted look the boy’s eyes. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GEORGES
dialogues.text: If you’ve ever wondered where your dreams come from, just look around. This is where they’re made. A technician calls to Young Georges:  71.

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN
dialogues.text: Think we got it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GEORGES
dialogues.text: (calls back) Very good ... But we need to change the scene... He glances back to Young Tabard.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GEORGES
dialogues.text: We need to add one ... more ... knight. Later... Young Tabard is now costumed as a knight, bravely fightin the mechanical dragon alongside other actors. He is having the time of his life. He will never forget this moment. Young Georges watches from the camera. Pleased. Georges looks into the camera ... Then we go into the camera ... we see the film zipping through the camera ... the image of the dragon battle bei recorded ... then the film being processed ... an emulsio bath ... the film being dried ... finally the film runnin through a movie projector... And the completed movie glowing from a screen... Young Tabard sits in a theatre, watching as the dragon ba is projected. His face. Amazed. Delighted. We leave the past as color returns and we are again at... INT. FILM ACADEMY -- TABARD’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: In the end, he made over 500 movies ... He was phenomenally popular in his day.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: But why did he stop?  72.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Up until today, I believed that he died in the war, like so many others.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Can we watch some of his movies?

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: I wish you could ... But time hasn't been kind to old movies... He goes to his desk. Unlocks a drawer. Reverently removes cannister of film.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: This is the only one that we know of that survived ... Out of hundreds ... One. Tabard is moved, looking at the single sad cannister of f He looks up at them.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: And still ... it is a masterpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabelle is accompanying Hugo on his rounds as he winds t clocks. They climb down the long ladder into the large clock suspended from the ceiling of the Grand Hall. He has his bucket of tools. Clock dials surround him on all four sides.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: ++. I think it’s the only way. He’ll be excited. Why wouldn’t he be? He checks his pocket watch, then uses a little screwdrive tinker with one of the clocks. Isabelle stays above on the ladder, pokes her head down:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Do you think I should tell Mama Jeanne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it has to be a surprise, like a magic trick. We have to have some ++. Panache.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (impressed with the word) Well done. Just then-- Through one of the clock faces-- Hugo sees the Station Inspector and Maximilian! Approaching. Stopping. Standing directly below the clock! Hugo urgently gestures up to her to be quiet:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Shhh! He points down. She sees the Station Inspector. A long beat. Hugo doesn’t dare breathe. The Station Inspector stands there, looking over the terminal. Then he starts to go. Hugo exhales. Safe. But... Then... The clock ticks over to 4:00 pm... The minute hand clicks straight up... Knocking Hugo’s little screwdriver away... It falls... Hugo grabs for it... Isabelle watches in horror... Hugo misses...  74. The screwdriver falls... It hits the bottom of the clock with a resounding...

dialogues.speaker: CLINK
dialogues.text: The Station Inspector stops. Turns. Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Monsieur Claude? Are you up there? +.. Monsieur Claude? Hugo looks up to Isabelle in panic. What should he do?! She mimes grabbing her throat: act like you have laryngit Hugo puts on a deep, scratchy voice:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (deep voice) Monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Is all well up there?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (deep voice) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You’re not ... inebriated, are you?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (deep voice) No, sir ... I have a sore throat.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Hmm. Well, be sure to check the clock on platform seven. By my calculation it is three minutes fast ... I will not have time running amok in my station.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (deep voice) Right away, sir. The Station Inspector goes. Maximilian gives a nasty glan back, but follows.  75. Hugo looks up at Isabelle. That was close!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock over platform seven. Hugo kneels to wind the clock, which is at foot level. Isabelle sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: +-. It’s the only way we'll find out everything ... Papa Georges will see that there are people who remember him. How can that be wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: (hesitant) I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Please, Isabelle ... My father, the Automaton, Papa Georges, it’s like a puzzle ... When we put it all together, something’s going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: A message from your father? He doesn’t look at her.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I just hope ... you won’t be disappointed. A beat as he works on the clock. Through the clock face she notices Monsieur Rouleau putti away his brushes for the day. His Surrealist painting is coming along well. She sees a passing WEALTHY COUPLE commenting unfavorably his painting. Monsieur Rouleau ignores them with dignity.  76.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Poor Monsieur Rouleau ... He works so hard. People just don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: He keeps at it though. He’s got a real ... purpose.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: (points) Could you hand me that? She hands him a tool from the bucket. She flops over on her back, looking up at him as he conti to work on the clock:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I mean ... Did you ever notice that all machines are made for some reason? They make you laugh, like Papa Georges’ toys, or they tell time, like the clocks ... Maybe that’s why broken machines always make me sad, because they can’t do what they’re meant to do. She looks up at him. From her perspective, he is beautifu framed by the intricate clockwork.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s the same with people. If you lose your purpose ... it’s like you're broken.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Like Papa Georges.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Maybe we can fix him. He continues to work on the clock. A beat as she watches him.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Is that your purpose?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: What?  77.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: That. Fixing things.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It’s what my father did.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I wonder what my purpose is?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t know. A long beat as she thinks about it. It seems to make her sad.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe if I had known my parents I would know. She gazes out over the terminal, a little lost. He looks at her. Senses her sadness. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enormous clock. The majestic view of Paris. The lights of the city are twinkling on. It is magical. T whole city seems to move and flow like an elegant, perfec machine. Hugo and Isabelle look over the city.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Right after my father died, I would come up here a lot ... I would imagine that the whole world was one big machine. Machines never have any extra parts, you know. They always have the exact number they need. So I figured if the entire world was a big machine I couldn’t be an extra part, I had to be here for some reason ... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HUGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that means you have to be here for some reason, too. She is touched. Paris sparkles below. Like it is made of stars. The only sound is the steady, rhythmic pulse of the clock machinery. She gently takes his hand. A huge full moon is rising. They are silhouetted before the glowing moon. And above them the solar system is spinning away in perfe order. The spheres in harmony. Like a great clockwork mechanism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is closing up the shop. His movement are slow and leaden. Hugo and Isabelle are hiding around a corner:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I‘1l bring them at seven o'clock tomorrow night. Don’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Not really ... But I think it’s the only way...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: To fix him. He nods. A beat. She impulsively gives him a quick kiss on the cheek. He is shocked. Then she runs to Georges at the Toy Booth. Hugo slips away.  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo watches from behind a clock face. He sees Georges and Isabelle leaving the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles are burning. Hugo is getting ready for bed. Carefully winding his big pocket watch. Hanging it on its special hook by the bed. He looks at the Automaton. The Automaton looks back at him. Hugo blows out the candles and settles into bed. He is nervous about tomorrow. Can’t sleep. The Automaton watches him. We hear the steady tick ... tick ... tick of Hugo’s pocke watch. The image melts to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +. tick ... tick ... tick ... We are inside Monsieur Rouleau’s Surrealist painting. There is nothing vague or fuzzy about this nightmare. It the crystal-clear clarity of Magritte. The crisp, bold co of Michael Powell. Hugo moves through the station tunnels, but they are distorted and endless. An insane maze with insane angles impossible perspectives. As Hugo weaves through the maze he sees some familiar faces... Down one tunnel ... Madame Emilie’s little dachshund runs past in the foreground ... as Monsieur Labisse moves past the background, reading aloud...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down another tunnel ... Monsieur Frick dances past with * Madame Emilie on the ceiling ... while below Monsieur Rou paints blazing animated flames on the wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all trapped in this endless labyrinth of tunnels Then Isabelle appears to offer guidance. Hugo smiles, goes to her. She offers her hand. He takes it. He looks up at her face. But it is not her! It is Georges. Ferocious and angry! Then-- Hugo is suddenly alone. Back in his apartment. He sits up on the edge of his bed. The nightmare is over. Tick ... tick ... tick... He hears the comforting sound of his pocket watch. But something is wrong. He glances over. The pocket watch isn’t hanging from anymore. He listens intently... Tick ... tick ... tick ... The sounds appears to be coming from... From him! He pulls his shirt aside to reveal-- His guts are a ticking, spinning clockwork-- He bolts up-- He is a machine! An Automaton! its hook  81. And the apartment around him is now an ENORMOUS MACHINE. and horrible. He is utterly surrounded. POUNDING pistons. GRINDING gears. SPINNING wheels. Then Hugo’s face-- Starts to melt away-- Beginning to be replaced by the impassive features of the Automaton-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Hugo jerks awake. Panting for air. He gets out of bed. Lights a candle. Sits. He won’t sleep anymore tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two young BOHEMIANS, living on a dilapidated houseboat on Seine. The Young Man writes a poem, mouthing the lines to himsel The Young Woman lazily dangles a fishing line into the ri and smokes a pipe. Very Gertrude Stein. Her lines catches. Ah, breakfast. She reels her catch in ... it’s heavy ... she lazily peek over the side of the boat ... and sees... Uncle Claude! His lifeless face staring up! She screams. People on the banks come running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo waits nervously outside Georges’ building. He checks big pocket watch. It is just after 7:00. Professor Tabard approaches. He carries something in a la wooden box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: This way, sir. He leads Tabard into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isabelle is pretending to read. Mama Jeanne is across the room, sewing. Georges is nowher be seen. There is a knock at the door. Isabelle gives a little yelp and jumps up:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: I'll get it! Jeanne removes her heavy glasses, curious, as Isabelle hurries to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Oh, what a surprise! Come in, come in... Hugo and Tabard enter.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: What is the meaning of this, Isabelle?

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Please don’t be mad.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: That young man is not welcome here.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: We found out who Papa Georges is. A beat as she stares at them. 82. The imposing Rene Tabard steps forward, polite and formal

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: I deeply apologize, Madame. I thought you were expecting us. I will leave immediately and return upon your request.  She looks

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Please, keep your voices down, my husband is sleeping. He hasn’t been well ... I... I’m afraid you will not be invited back.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Don’t make them leave...

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: I don’t want to impose on you, Madame Melies, but if this is to be the only time we meet, please let me express to you the profound debt of gratitude I owe your husband. at him.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: When I was boy I saw all his films. They inspired me ... Your husband is a very great artist. She is touched.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: I’m pleased that you remember my husband's films with such fondness, but he’s become so fragile ... It only hurts him to remember the past.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: (bows ) Then we will take our leave, Madame .-. And I do hope you'll forgive me for saying, you are as lovely now as you were in the movies. Hugo and Isabelle are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Mama Jeanne...?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You were in the movies?

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: She appeared in almost all of his films.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: You were an actress?! 83.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: That was a long time ago, children. Another life ... I was another person.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Would you like to meet her again? Mama Jeanne looks at him, curious.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: We have a film.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: One of Georges’ films...? But that’s not possible. They’re all gone.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: May we show you? Hugo and Isabelle implore Mama Jeanne:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Oh, please...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Please, Mama Jeanne... Mama Jeanne glances quickly to the closed bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Be quick with it. Rene Tabard opens the wooden box. It contains a portable movie projector. He sets it up, plugs it in, and threads film, as:

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: An actress! A cinema actress! It’s impossibly romantic!

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t like that. We weren’t movie stars like they have now ... (a certain twinkle in her eye) But we did have fun. Tabard has finished. The projector is ready to go. Facing blank wall.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Madame Melies?  85. She nods. Tabard turns on the projector. Flickering white light. A TRIP TO THE MOON. We see selections from the fantastical Georges Melies fil giving us a sense of this delightful movie. For Mama Jeanne the emotion is overwhelming. Like seeing past come to life. Her eyes fill with tears. The wizard-like Astronomers argue in the great hall. The rocket is constructed in a busy workshop. The huge ca is tested. Then it is time for the rocket to be launched. Pretty girls line up and usher the five voyagers into the rocket. During this sequence one particular girl is featured. She is in the foreground. Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: Mama Jeanne ... it’s you!

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Yes... The great cannon is fired. Then the famous sequence. We zoom toward the moon. The fa of the man in the moon appears. The rocket hits him in th right eye! He reacts. Once we reach the moon, the movie is in color. Lovely and diffused. Pale pastels.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: It’s color!

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: We tinted the film ... Painted it by hand. The voyagers move around the lunar surface. The earth ris over the horizon. Fantasy images of comets shooting past, stars, planets, constellations. Then it snows and the voyagers go into a crater.  86. Inside the moon, a weird landscape. Bizarre Moon Creature appear. The voyagers battle them. The Moon Creatures disappear magically in puffs of smoke. The voyagers escape into the rocket. It is pulled off the edge of the moon. The rocket soars back to earth. It splashes into the ocea and goes underwater. An enchanting bottom-of-the-sea sett The rocket is finally towed back to shore. The movie ends. The film tail flips around. The white light flickers. A beat. Mama Jeanne is drying her eyes. Isabelle takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE
dialogues.text: You were so beautiful. A voice, from behind them:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She still is. They turn. Georges is standing in the doorway. He has seen it all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I would recognize the sound of a movie projector anywhere. Mama Jeanne goes to him and holds him closely. She helps him to sit. He is emotionally drained. She looks at Georges deeply.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: Georges ... You've tried to forget the past for so long, and that’s brought you nothing but unhappiness -.. Maybe it’s time to remember.  87. She takes his hands in hers.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA JEANNE
dialogues.text: I remember the man I fell in love with ... I don’t want to lose him forever. A long moment between them. Georges kisses her hands. He turns, studies Hugo.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: You want to know?

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Yes. A beat. So be it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Like you ... I loved to fix things... The color drains from the scene as Georges remembers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the flashbacks earlier, Georges’ story has the quali of a SILENT FILM. Flickering gaslight. We see YOUNG GEORGES on stage. YOUNG JEANNE is his assistant. They do a magic trick.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I started out as a magician, and Mama Jeanne was my assistant. We were very successful, I must say. We even had our own theatre...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Georges is tinkering with something mechanical we d see.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I was always tinkering with machines. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had my own workshop at the theatre where I could invent new illusions ... Once I even built a working Automaton. Ah, he was a particular treasure. I put my heart and soul into him... We see that Young Georges has been working on the Automaton...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Georges and Young Jeanne enjoy a night at a traveli circus. They move past sideshow tents.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then one night, Mama Jeanne and I went to visit a traveling circus. We were walking past the sideshow tents when I noticed something ... Something strange ... Something wonderful... In the distance, Young Georges sees bright light flickeri magically from one of the sideshow tents. The light draws like a moth to a flame...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Georges and Young Jeanne are in the sideshow tent. Watching a very early movie. Both are transported.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Lumiere brothers had invented the movies. I fell in love with their invention. How could I not be a part of it? It was like a new kind of magic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Georges uses spare pieces from the Automaton to mak movie camera. It is a beautiful and elaborate creation.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I asked the Lumiere brothers to sell me a camera, but they refused. You see they were convinced the movies were only a passing fad and didn’t want me to waste my money! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I built my own camera using leftover pieces from the Automaton...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the country, outside Paris. Young Georges and Young Je pose proudly in front of their new studio as a photograph exposes a picture.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We risked everything ... We sold the theatre and everything we had so we could build our own movie studio...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filming one of Georges’ movies. He’s a bundle of energy. Currently perfecting a special pyrotechnic effect scene, with himself as the star. Young Jeanne tries to keep order in the chaotic studio.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so the great adventure began! I wrote, designed, directed and acted in hundreds of movies. Magic tricks and illusion became my specialty; the world of imagination ... Georges does a simple special effect: he poses, a puff of smoke in front of him, the camera stops, he leaves the se the camera starts: a disappearing man. Young Jeanne laughs and helps clean the black powder off face:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My beautiful wife was my muse, my star, and we couldn’t have been happier ... We thought it would never end. How could it? Suddenly-- More pyrotechnics -- but different now -- the EXPLOSION O BOMBS -- flashes of light -- trenches and barbed wire -- horrible rattle of machine guns -- iconic images of the F World War--  90. Taking us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain. Sodden flags. Georges, older now, watches a line of French soldiers march off to war. Like tragic toy soldier

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But then the war came, and youth and hope were at an end... The world had no time for magic tricks and movie shows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges stands at the rear of a theatre. One of his fanci movies is playing. Many veteran soldiers are in the audie Smoking. Making out with girlfriends. Bored.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The returning soldiers, having seen so much of reality, were bored by my films ... Tastes had changed, but I had not changed with them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIME LAPSE ... the beautiful greenhouse studio decays ... windows crack and break ... weeds spring up ... the gorge set pieces rot ... the roof falls ... rain splashes in... the studio is boarded up and abandoned...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No one wanted my movies anymore. Eventually I couldn’t pay the actors or keep the business running .-.. And so my enchanted castle fell to ruin ... Everything was lost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges stands in the ruins of his studio. A great bonfire is roaring. We see a huge painted version the famous moon face from A TRIP TO THE MOON burning. Georges, in anguish, is tossing costumes into the pyre.  91.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One night, in bitter despair, I burned all my old sets and costumes +--+. I was forced to sell my movies to a company that melted them down into chemicals used to make shoe heels... A sudden flare from the bonfire-- Transforms to-- A reel of old movie film -- bursting into flames, blazing then melting-- The liquid is poured into a mold -- a shoe heel emerges f the mold -- it is nailed onto a shoe-- The shoe walks past the Toy Booth in the Train Station...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is in the Toy Booth. It looks much the same, only newer. It is like a prison.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With the little money I made from selling my films I bought the toy booth ... And there I have remained... Georges sits at the counter. He stares out. Lost. Dead-eyed. The color gradually returns... And Georges’ face ages to now... As we return to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --. Georges’s face. He concludes the story:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: The only thing I couldn’t bring myself to destroy was my beloved Automaton. I gave him to a museum, hoping he would find a home. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But they never put him on display. And then the museum burned ... It’s all gone now. Everything I ever made ... Nothing but ashes and fading strips of celluloid. He looks at Hugo deeply. Proceeds with difficulty:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: My life has taught me one lesson, Hugo ... Not the one I thought it would ... Happy endings only happen in the movies.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: The story’s not over yet. He stands. Excited.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I’1l be right back! He shares a secret look with Isabelle and then runs out. Georges is mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo races through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, the train station is bustling. Monsieur Frick is walking through the Grand Hall. He carr a large picnic basket and has a rather crafty expression. He approaches Madame Emilie’s cafe. Madame Emilie is pleased to see him. Her dachshund is not begins to growl menacingly. This time, however, Monsieur Frick is not deterred. He approaches bravely. The dachshund growls more. About to attack. Then...  93. Monsieur Frick reaches into the picnic basket... And removes... Another little dachshund. With a pink ribbon around its neck. Madame Emilie’s dachshund is instantly smitten. The two d nuzzle affectionately. Monsieur Frick, the conquering hero, steps forward boldly takes Madame Emilie’s hand and kisses it. She blushes. Just then, Hugo appears. He is moving quickly toward one of the air vents past the cafe. But he ducks to the side when the Station Inspector and Maximilian approach the cafe ... Lisette wanders over fro the flower stall to join them. Hugo, hidden nearby, overhears:

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: There has been ... a disquieting development.

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR FRICK
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: The man who winds the clocks, Monsieur Claude, has been found -- deceased. Lisette gasps. Hugo stiffens, listens intently.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: They found his body in the Seine. He’s been down there for months it seems. Amongst the fishes. And such.

dialogues.speaker: MADAME EMILIE
dialogues.text: Oh dear, oh dear. Meanwhile, the two dachshunds are sniffing around. They wander over to where Hugo is hiding. He tries desperately to shoo them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximilian notices the dachshunds. He pulls at his leash investigate. The Station Inspector restrains him.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: I can’t say I’m surprised this was his mortal culmination. He was an inebriant of the highest order. Time and again I had to warn him about it ... These are the wages of sin!

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR FRICK
dialogues.text: But if Monsieur Claude has been dead for months...

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR FRICK
dialogues.text: At the bottom of the river...

dialogues.speaker: MADAME EMILIE
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR FRICK
dialogues.text: Then who has been winding the clocks? Just then -- the dachshunds begin BARKING like crazy at H Maximilian pulls free-- The Station Inspector sees Hugo--! Hugo bolts, but not fast enough-- Maximilian bounds -- leaps in front of him -- snarling ferociously-- Hugo freezes, terrified-- The Station Inspector grabs him. Captured. At last! INT. TRAIN STATION -- CORRIDOR/INSPECTOR’S OFFICE - NIGHT The Station Inspector drags Hugo through the corridor/sta and into his office...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You don’t understand -- I have to go!  95.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You’1l go nowhere until your parents can be found.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I don’t have any parents!

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Then it’1l be straight to the orphanage with you, little vermin. He flings Hugo into the dreadful little cell and slams th door shut with a resounding clang. Hugo clings to the bar

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You and your kind. Spreading disorder everywhere you go. WELL

dialogues.speaker: ORDER
dialogues.text: The Station Inspector's fury echoes around the office. He turns away to his desk... Hugo quickly pulls out the lock-picking tool he used before... The Stations Inspector picks up the phone, taps the cradl for a connection...

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, hello? hello? ... Connect me with the Orphanage Bureau. Quickly. I need to arrange a... He glances back to Hugo-- The cell door is open! Hugo is gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo clatters down the stairs outside the Station Inspect office-- The Station Inspector appears and follows, remarkably agi down the stairs, using the handrails to swing--

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: (calls) Maximilian! Hugo reaches the floor of the terminal--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximilian, who is with the two dachshunds, bolts after h The dachshunds takes off as well-- Hugo weaves wildly through the terminal. But the Station Inspector is gaining, spidering quickly a him, his leg brace squeaking. The dachshunds race along. Barking madly. Maximilian following. Hugo cuts a path through a crowd of commuters. The Station Inspector nears, a step or two away-- He reaches for Hugo-- But Hugo has unexpected allies. Monsieur Labisse “accidentally” steps in front of the Sta Inspector, stopping him--

dialogues.speaker: MONSIEUR LABISSE
dialogues.text: Oh, do pardon me! Hugo speeds away. Shoots Monsieur Labisse a thankful glance. The Station Inspector rights himself and races after Hugo Maximilian and the yapping dachshunds follow close at Hug heels. But Hugo has another unexpected ally. Monsieur Rouleau, munching on a baguette as he walks thro the station, sees the situation-- He tosses his baguette like a bowler-- It slides across the floor-- Hugo leaps over it-- The dachshunds, being dachshunds, instantly veer off, pursuing the food-- Hugo’s free of them. He disappears around a corner.  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Station Inspector and Maximilian round the corner aft Hugo-— But Hugo has disappeared! Then the Station Inspector notices a manhole cover in the floor is slightly ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo is swiftly climbing down a ladder. He jumps down to large mechanized turntable: where entire streetcars and m trains pull in and are rotated to face different tunnels. Tunnels shoot off in six directions. Hugo hears the Station Inspector clattering and squeaking down the ladder after him. Hugo looks around. Sees an access panel leading down unde the turntable, into the workings of the machine. He climbs through the access panel and disappears just as Station Inspector spiders down the ladder after him. Beneath: Hugo is surrounded by the great gears and cogs o the turntable mechanism: huge wheels and springs and pist like a gigantic clock. He can see the Station Inspector r above. Looking for him. Incredible suspense as the Station Inspector searches. Hugo is silent ... Artfully slipping between the mammoth gears as the Station Inspector looks down through open sl in the floor, hunting for him... The Station Inspector peers down ... Hugo silently crawls between great cogs to stay hidden ... The Station Inspect doesn’t see him... But then -- the Station Inspector sees that a train is co into the turntable! He quickly moves to the ladder and climbs out. But Hugo can’t. He’s trapped. The train or streetcar rumbles in right above him. Hugo covers his ears at the seismic roar. Ashes and sparks rai down. The train stops.  98. Hugo waits. Then... The turntable starts to move. The great gears turn ... the pistons stab ... the cogs gr .-. Hugo dives to avoid the pistons ... slithers between cogs and gears that engulf him, like teeth trying to devo him-- It's like Chaplin in MODERN TIMES. Hugo’s is trapped insi huge machine as it grinds and pounds and turns -- threate to crush him from every side... He slips, slides, jumps and maneuvers. Just managing to a being crushed... Then it’s over. The turntable stops. The train rumbles of down a different tunnel. Hugo finally dares to peek through the access panel. No s of the Station Inspector. He climbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo moves through the tunnels. Then he hears a sound echoing ominously ... a low growl . Maximilian ... No idea where it’s coming from... Hugo stops. Looks. The growl is closer now! But from where?! Hugo looks around in desperation. Tunnels in every direct Hugo is by the long stairway leading up to the tower. He decides to escape that way. He disappears up the stairway Just as the Station Inspector and Maximilian round a corn They stop. Look in various directions. Which way did he g Maximilian sniffs. He indicates the steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo’s feet pound. His legs pump. He pants for air. Climbing, climbing, climbing.  99. The long stairway seems to stretch out wildly below. Like VERTIGO. The Station Inspector and Maximilian pursue. Churning up long stairway below Hugo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo emerges at the very top of the station. He looks around in panic. He hears the Station Inspector and Maximilian coming up t stairs. Huffing and puffing. Feet pounding. Nails clickin Leg brace squeaking. Closer and closer. Hugo’s trapped. Or is he? He takes a deep breath. Then... He climbs through the enormous clock face. Until he is clinging to the outside of the clock! A deadly drop below. Just like Harold Lloyd in SAFETY LAST. Inside, the Station Inspector and Maximilian appear. The Station Inspector Looks around. Puzzled. Maximilian sniffs. Confused. Then, outside... The enormous hour hand that Hugo is clinging to... Lurches... Almost breaks... Hugo clings to it desperately, echoing the iconic image f SAFETY LAST. The abyss below is terrifying. Hugo doesn’t dare cry out.  100. Inside, the Station Inspector grunts.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Must have gone the other way. Come! He leads Maximilian back down the stairs. Outside, Hugo carefully pulls himself to safety. He sits ledge for a moment. Getting his breath. He looks over Paris. Shakes his head. What a night! He climbs back through the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo is lugging the Automaton, wrapped in a blanket, thro the terminal. It is slow going, but he does his best. He keeps a wary eye out for the Station Inspector and Maximilian. He sees the two villainous dachshunds at the cafe. He chooses to avoid them. Goes in another direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo moves along a platform. A train has just arrived. Scores of commuters are climbing off the train and scurry along the platform. They jostle Hugo. He continues on. Then... Behind him... We see...  101. A bottle-green coat. The Station Inspector. Following. Oddly, no sign of Maximilian. Hugo shifts the heavy Automaton, trying to make it easier carry as he pushes through the crowd. The Station Inspector nears... Hugo doesn’t see him... The Station Inspector reaches out for Hugo... But then Hugo sees the Station Inspector’s image, reflect in a window of the train. Hugo cleverly nips into the train--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hugo pushes through the crowd of people inside the train- The Station Inspector pursues, calling:

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Stand aside! Hugo nips out the other side of the train--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He emerges to the platform-- Where-- Maximilian is waiting! Hugo lurches to a stop-- The Station Inspector lunges from the train, grabbing Hug arm-— Swinging him around-- Hugo loses his grip-- The Automaton flies from Hugo’s arms!  102. Time slows as... The beautiful machine falls through the air... Tumbling end-over-end... Falling slowly toward the empty train tracks of the next platform over... Finally... Crashing down! And there’s a train coming along these tracks-- Barreling out of the station-- Picking up speed-- Hugo doesn’t hesitate-- He jerks his arm free-- Jumps down-- Onto the tracks! The train is nearing. Coming straight at Hugo. Just like early movie we saw before, A TRAIN ARRIVES IN THE STATION The train gets bigger and bigger as it approaches. Hugo grabs the Automaton. The train’s whistle howls. Someone screams. A hand reaches down for Hugo. The train. Closer and closer. The metallic screech of the train’s brakes. Hugo thrusts his hand up. The Station Inspector clasps his hand. At the last possible moment, Hugo is yanked off the track safety. He still clings to the Automaton. A shower of sparks from the train’s wheels as it passes. Hugo and the Automaton fall awkwardly to the platform.  103. The Station Inspector and the crowd are stunned. They pre in. Questioning. Scolding. Poking. Talking. Hugo only cares about the Automaton. It is broken and battered. Hugo pulls it to him. Clings to it desperately.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You demented animal! What were you thinking?! Before Hugo can respond the Station Inspector hauls him a - stomping off, cutting through the crowd -- dragging Hug Hugo still clinging to the Automaton--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move through the busy Grand Hall. Hugo struggles to himself from the Station Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: We'll let the orphanage deal with you!

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: No! -- I don’t belong there!

dialogues.speaker: STATION INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Where do you belong then? A child has to belong to somewhere and to someone! Hugo finally wrenches himself free. Holds the Automaton t his chest. His emotion is overwhelming. Tears choking him.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Please ... Please listen to me ... You have to let me go ... I don’t understand ... why my father died -.. why I’m alone.... He clings to the Automaton.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: This is my only chance ... To work. He glances at the Station Inspector’s leg brace.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: You should understand.  104. By now a little crowd has formed around them ... Monsieur Frick ... Madame Emile ... Lisette... And two new arrivals: Georges and Isabelle. Georges has heard everything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: I do ... I do understand. He looks at the Station Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Monsieur ... This child belongs to me. The Station Inspector looks at him. And then the Station Inspector smiles. A kind and effortl smile. He releases Hugo. Hugo crosses to Georges and Isabelle. He still holds the Automaton to him closely:

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: I’m sorry ... He’s broken...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: No he’s not ... He worked perfectly. He embraces Hugo. And then we see them from high above... Hugo, Georges, Isabelle, the Automaton... The train station swirling around them ... Passengers mov to and fro... Like the gears and wheels of a clock... A precise, beautiful machine. Then we iris down to black. A title appears: SIX MONTHS LATER. We iris back up again to...  105. The famous man in the moon face from A TRIP TO THE MOON..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .-. Which is painted on the curtain of the impressive Fil Academy theatre. The theatre is filled with elegant guests. A buzzing crow gala event. Hugo, Isabelle and Mama Jeanne sit together. Hugo has had a haircut. His new, short hair is combed nea into place. He is wearing a tuxedo. Very handsome. He looks almost grown up. Isabelle, next to him, is bewitching in a formal dress. The lights dim. Rene Tabard steps to the stage, in front of the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: Honored guests, I am proud to welcome you to this gala celebrating the life and work of Georges Melies. Applause. Mama Jeanne begins to cry. Isabelle takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: For years most of his films were thought to be lost. Indeed, Monsieur Melies believed so himself. But we began a search. We looked through vaults and long- forgotten archives, through private collections, barns and catacombs. Our work was rewarded with old negatives, boxes of prints, and trunks full of decaying film, which we were able to save ... We now have over eighty films by Georges Melies! Applause.  106.

dialogues.speaker: TABARD
dialogues.text: And tonight their creator ... and the newest member of the Film Academy faculty ... is here to share them with you. He turns and bows. The magnificent man-in-the-moon curtain parts to reveal.. Georges. Standing center stage. A movie screen behind him. His hair and beard have been neatly trimmed. He wears an elegant tuxedo and looks extremely distinguished. The audience erupts in cheers and applause. Finally they are quiet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen ... I am standing before you tonight because of one very brave young man... He finds Hugo’s face in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: He saw a broken machine. And against all odds, he fixed it ... It was the kindest magic trick I have ever seen. Hugo is moved. Isabelle looks at him, proud.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES
dialogues.text: Now, my friends, I address you all tonight as you truly are: wizards, mermaids, travelers, adventurers, and magicians ... Come and dream with me. He turns toward the movie screen... The lights dim... A flickering projector’s light shines... And we enter the joyous world of Georges Melies.  It is a cornucopia of images from a golden horn. A phantasmagoria of... Undersea kingdoms... Magic tricks... Wildly dancing devils... Mysterious submarine journeys... Gigantic monsters... Beautiful damsels... Soaring palaces... Wondrous balloon voyages... Knock-about slapstick... Expanding heads... Frolicking skeletons... Lovely star-like angels... And... A trip to the moon. Hugo is barely watching the screen. He is looking at something else: Georges stands to the side of the stage, watching. The glow from the screen illuminates Georges’ face. He is like a man reborn. Hugo looks at him. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A party. After the gala. The small apartment is crowded with well-wishers and We float through the party... 107. friends.  108. Georges is talking closely to Rene Tabard. Film students other fans crowd around Georges ... He winks to Mama Jean across the room. She winks back... We continue on... Monsieur Frick and Madame Emilie sit together. The dachsh happy on their laps... We continue on... Monsieur Rouleau talks to Monsieur Labisse about books an art. Monsieur Rouleau’s completed painting hangs on a wal We continue on... The Station Inspector sits with Lisette and Maximilian. Actually, Maximilian sits between them. He’s unsure what make of this new-found romance. We continue on... To find... Hugo is dominating a corner of the party, doing wonderful cards tricks. The crowd around him is impressed. He glances over, smiles to Isabelle across the room. She smiles back. A beat as she watches him. Then we go with Isabelle as she moves to a quiet corner. looks over the party for a moment. Then she sits and begins to write in a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once upon a time, I met a boy named Hugo Cabret. He lived in a train station... We move away from Isabelle... Past Hugo... Past Georges and Mama Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why did he live in a train station? You might well ask ... That’s really what this book is going to be about...  109. We move into Hugo’s room... The Automaton, nicely repaired, is watching from a corner We go to the Automaton...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And about how this singular young man searched so hard to find a secret message from his father... The Automaton’s face... Looking through the open doorway into the party...

dialogues.speaker: ISABELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And how that message lit his way --- all the way home. The Automaton watches Hugo. You would swear it was smiling. The End.
